title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Bed formatted consensus matrix (chr, start, end samples) Create contrasts want compare, create contrasts 22 mice samples different strains. cinaR function directly computes differentially accessible peaks. Now, can access differential accessibility (DA) enrichment results. Inside DA.results, consensus peaks (cp) differentially accessible (DA) peaks. batch correction run, cp batch-corrected consensus matrix, otherwise filtered normalized version original consensus peaks provided. many information cinaR provides adjusted p value, log fold-changes, gene names etc peak: overview DA peaks: Since comparison B6_NZO, fold-changes positive means accesible B6 compared NZO vice versa negative values! little overview enrichment analyses results:
code: library(cinaR) data("atac_seq_consensus_bm") dim(bed) ## [1] 1000   25 # bed formatted file head(bed[,1:4]) ##         Chr     Start       End B6-18mo-M-BM-47-GT18-01783 ## 52834  chr5  24841478  24845196                       1592 ## 29780 chr17   8162955   8164380                        109 ## 67290  chr8  40577584  40578029                         72 ## 51295  chr4 145277698 145278483                        110 ## 4267   chr1 180808752 180815472                       2452 ## 45102  chr3  88732151  88732652                         49 # create contrast vector which will be compared. contrasts<- c("B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO",                "B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO") # If reference genome is not set hg38 will be used! results <- cinaR(bed, contrasts, reference.genome = "mm10") ## >> preparing features information...      2026-02-02 12:28:24  ## >> Using Genome: mm10 ... ## >> identifying nearest features...        2026-02-02 12:28:25  ## >> calculating distance from peak to TSS...   2026-02-02 12:28:25  ## >> assigning genomic annotation...        2026-02-02 12:28:25  ## >> Using Genome: mm10 ... ## >> Using Genome: mm10 ... ## >> assigning chromosome lengths           2026-02-02 12:28:39  ## >> done...                    2026-02-02 12:28:39 names(results) ## [1] "DA.results"         "Enrichment.Results" names(results$DA.results) ## [1] "cp"       "DA.peaks" colnames(results$DA.results$DA.peaks$B6_NZO) ##  [1] "Row.names"     "seqnames"      "start"         "end"           ##  [5] "width"         "strand"        "annotation"    "geneChr"       ##  [9] "geneStart"     "geneEnd"       "geneLength"    "geneStrand"    ## [13] "geneId"        "transcriptId"  "distanceToTSS" "gene_name"     ## [17] "logFC"         "FDR" head(results$DA.results$DA.peaks$B6_NZO[,1:5]) ##                  Row.names seqnames     start       end width ## 1 chr1_134559439_134560787     chr1 134559439 134560787  1349 ## 2 chr1_138158514_138159483     chr1 138158514 138159483   970 ## 3 chr1_164247654_164251852     chr1 164247654 164251852  4199 ## 4 chr1_171631196_171631780     chr1 171631196 171631780   585 ## 5 chr1_173954537_173955745     chr1 173954537 173955745  1209 ## 6 chr1_177935969_177936852     chr1 177935969 177936852   884 head(results$Enrichment.Results$B6_NZO[,c("module.name","overlapping.genes", "adj.p")]) ##                 module.name                   overlapping.genes      adj.p ## 1         Myeloid lineage 1 TFEB,FBXL5,PLXNC1,GM2A,AGTPBP1,CTSB 0.06643636 ## 2  U_metabolism/replication             SLC2A6,GM2A,CTSB,PECAM1 0.06643636 ## 3  U_mitochondrial proteins     PIK3R1,PAQR3,UBE3A,MAP4K4,PTPRC 0.36971894 ## 4 U_proteasome/ubiquitin cx                  PIK3R1,IREB2,PTPRC 0.42321080 ## 5   U_Immunity/cytoskeleton                          RPS6,RPS19 0.70414223 ## 6         Myeloid lineage 2                        RNF157,MTUS1 0.70947467

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: can easily get PCA plots samples:  can overlay different information onto PCA plots well!
code: pca_plot(results, contrasts, show.names = F) # Overlaid information overlaid.info <- c("B6-18mo", "B6-18mo", "B6-18mo", "B6-18mo", "B6-18mo",                     "NZO-18mo", "NZO-18mo", "NZO-18mo", "NZO-18mo", "NZO-18mo", "NZO-18mo",                     "B6-3mo", "B6-3mo", "B6-3mo", "B6-3mo", "B6-3mo",                     "NZO-3mo", "NZO-3mo", "NZO-3mo", "NZO-3mo", "NZO-3mo", "NZO-3mo") # Sample IDs sample.names <- c("S01783", "S01780", "S01781", "S01778", "S01779",  "S03804", "S03805", "S03806", "S03807", "S03808",  "S03809", "S04678", "S04679", "S04680", "S04681",  "S04682", "S10918", "S10916", "S10919", "S10921",  "S10917", "S10920") pca_plot(results, overlaid.info, sample.names)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: can see available comparisons using: , plot differential peaks selected contrast using:  Also, can configure heatmaps using additional arguments pheatmap function. information check ?pheatmap.
code: show_comparisons(results) ## [1] "B6_NZO" heatmap_differential(results, comparison = "B6_NZO") heatmap_differential(results, comparison = "B6_NZO", show_colnames = FALSE)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: can also plot variable 100 peaks samples:  Plus, can set number peaks used plots, can change additional arguments pheatmap function. information check ?pheatmap.
code: heatmap_var_peaks(results) heatmap_var_peaks(results, heatmap.peak.count = 200, cluster_cols = F)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: can plot enrichment results using:  gets crowded, can get rid irrelevant pathways well:
code: dot_plot(results) ## Warning: Removed 54 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range ## (`geom_point()`). dot_plot(results, filter.pathways = T)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Note can divide resolution contrasts, instance also valid vector case, compared result 28 different comparisons.
code: contrasts <- sapply(strsplit(colnames(bed), split = "-", fixed = T),                      function(x){paste(x[1:4], collapse = ".")})[4:25] unique(contrasts) ## [1] "B6.18mo.M.BM"  "B6.18mo.F.BM"  "NZO.18mo.F.BM" "NZO.18mo.M.BM" ## [5] "B6.3mo.F.BM"   "B6.3mo.M.BM"   "NZO.3mo.F.BM"  "NZO.3mo.M.BM"

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: default, cinaR use one vs one (OVA) scheme, comparing contrast others one one. However, can changed one vs (OVA) compare contrast rest:
code: # one-vs-one (results in n choose k comparisons, default) cinaR(..., comparison.scheme = "OVO")  # one-vs-all (results in n comparisons) cinaR(..., comparison.scheme = "OVA")

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: run cinaR RNA-seq experiments, just provide count matrix, specify experiment type: Note , count.matrix form g×(1+n)g \times (1+n) gg number genes nn number samples, plus one gene names. Note currently cinaR can handle gene symbols (e.g. FOSL2, FOXA) ensembl stable IDs (e.g. ENSG00000010404) human mice!
code: cinaR(matrix = count.matrix, ..., experiment.type = "RNA-Seq")

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: cinaR designed bulk ATAC-seq. 10x scATAC, first pseudobulk peak--cell matrix preserve biological replicates, run cinaR resulting consensus matrix. can pass prep$bed prep$contrasts cinaR() usual. use Seurat/Signac object, can prepare data directly:
code: set.seed(1) counts <- matrix(rpois(4 * 8, lambda = 2), nrow = 4) rownames(counts) <- c("chr1:1-100", "chr1:101-200", "chr2:1-150", "chr2:151-300") colnames(counts) <- paste0("cell", 1:8)  meta <- data.frame(   sample = c("S1", "S1", "S2", "S2", "S3", "S3", "S4", "S4"),   group = c("A", "A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B", "B"),   row.names = colnames(counts),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  prep <- prep_scATAC_cinaR(   counts,   meta,   sample.col = "sample",   group.col = "group",   min.cells = 2 )  dim(prep$bed) ## [1] 4 7 prep$contrasts ##  S1  S2  S3  S4  ## "A" "A" "B" "B" prep <- prep_scATAC_seurat(seurat_obj,                            sample.col = "sample",                            group.col = "group",                            assay = "peaks")

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: can run enrichment analyses custom gene set:
code: cinaR(..., geneset = new_geneset)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Easiest way use cinaRgenesets package. can select gene set interest just plug pipeline.

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: can also download different gene sets MSigDB site. Note use human gene symbol versions. can use read.gmt function qusage package read genesets current environment.

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: geneset must .gmt formatted symbol file. can familiarize format checking : gene pathway names data.frame, can use split function create .gmt formatted gene sets e.g. split(df$genes, df$pathways).
code: # default geneset to be used data("VP2008")

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: now, cinaR supports 3 genomes human mice models: hg38 hg19 mm10 can set using reference.genome argument.

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: suspect data unknown batch effects, can use: option run Surrogate Variable Analysis (SVA) try adjust data unknown batch effects. however, already know batches samples, can simply set batch.information argument well. run SVA just add batches design matrix. Reminder - example data 22 samples
code: cinaR(..., batch.correction = T) # runs SVA cinaR(..., batch.correction = T)  # runs SVA with 2 surrogate variables cinaR(..., batch.correction = T, sv.number = 2)  # adds only batch information to the design matrix! (does not run SVA) # batch.information should be number a vector where # the length of it equals to the number of samples. cinaR(..., batch.correction = T, batch.information = c(rep(0, 11), rep(1,11)))

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Sometimes, one might want add additional covariates adjust design matrix , affects -stream analyses. instance, ages sexes samples additional covariates. account :
code: # Ages of the samples could be not in biological interests but should be accounted for! cinaR(..., additional.covariates = c((18, 11), (3, 11)))  # More than one covariate for instance, sex and age sex.info <- c("M", "F", "M", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "M", "M", "M",                "F", "F", "M", "M", "M", "F", "F", "M", "M", "F", "M")  age.info <- c((18, 11), (3, 11) covs <- data.frame(Sex = sex.info, Age = age.info)  cinaR(..., additional.covariates = covs)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Setting save.DA.peaks = TRUE cinaR function create DApeaks.xlsx file current directory. file includes comparisons different tabs. Additionally, can set path/name file using DA.peaks.path argument setting save.DA.peaks = TRUE. instance, create excel file name Peaks_mice.xlsx current directory.
code: results <- cinaR(..., save.DA.peaks = T, DA.peaks.path = "./Peaks_mice.xlsx")

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Currently, cinaR supports 4 different algorithms, namely; edgeR limma-voom limma-trend DESeq2 set, uses edgeR differential analyses. can change used algorithm simply setting DA.choice argument. information, ?cinaR

title: Introduction to cinaR
code: # new FDR threshold for DA peaks results <- cinaR(..., DA.fdr.threshold = 0.1)  # filters out pathways results <- cinaR(..., enrichment.FDR.cutoff = 0.1)  # does not run enrichment pipeline results <- cinaR(..., run.enrichment = FALSE)  # creates the piechart from chIpSeeker package results <- cinaR(..., show.annotation.pie = TRUE)  # change cut-off value for dot plots dot_plot(..., fdr.cutoff = 0.05)

title: Introduction to cinaR
text: Robinson MD, McCarthy DJ, Smyth GK (2010). “edgeR: Bioconductor package differential expression analysis digital gene expression data.” Bioinformatics, 26(1), 139-140. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btp616. Ritchie , Phipson B, Wu D, Hu Y, Law CW, Shi W, Smyth GK (2015). “limma powers differential expression analyses RNA-sequencing microarray studies.” Nucleic Acids Research, 43(7), e47. Love, M.., Huber, W., Anders, S. (2014) Moderated estimation fold change dispersion RNA-seq data DESeq2. Genome Biology, 15:550. 10.1186/s13059-014-0550-8

title: Introduction to cinaR

title: Authors and Citation
text: Onur Karakaslar. Author, maintainer. Duygu Ucar. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Karakaslar E, Ucar D (2021). “cinaR: comprehensive R package differential analyses functional interpretation ATAC-seq data.” bioRxiv. doi:10.1101/2021.03.05.434143, https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.03.05.434143v2.
code: @Article{,   title = {cinaR: A comprehensive R package for the differential analyses and functional interpretation of ATAC-seq data},   author = {E Onur Karakaslar and Duygu Ucar},   year = {2021},   journal = {bioRxiv},   doi = {10.1101/2021.03.05.434143},   url = {https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.03.05.434143v2}, }

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
text: cinaR single wrapper function end--end computational analyses bulk ATAC-seq (RNA-seq) profiles. Starting consensus peak file, outputs differentially accessible peaks, enrichment results, provides users various configurable visualization options. details, please see preprint.

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
code: # CRAN mirror install.packages("cinaR")

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
text: get bug fix use feature development version:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("eonurk/cinaR")

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
text: Sometimes bioconductor related packages may installed automatically. Therefore, may need install manually:
code: BiocManager::install(c("ChIPseeker", "DESeq2", "edgeR", "fgsea","GenomicRanges", "limma", "preprocessCore", "sva", "TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene", "TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg19.knownGene", "TxDb.Mmusculus.UCSC.mm10.knownGene"))

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
code: library(cinaR) #> Checking for required Bioconductor packages... #> All required Bioconductor packages are already installed.  # create contrast vector which will be compared. contrasts<- c("B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO",                "B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "B6", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO", "NZO")  # If reference genome is not set hg38 will be used! results <- cinaR(bed, contrasts, reference.genome = "mm10") #> >> Experiment type: ATAC-Seq #> >> Matrix is filtered! #>  #> >> preparing features information...      2024-05-22 12:38:01  #> >> identifying nearest features...        2024-05-22 12:38:02  #> >> calculating distance from peak to TSS...   2024-05-22 12:38:02  #> >> assigning genomic annotation...        2024-05-22 12:38:02  #> >> assigning chromosome lengths           2024-05-22 12:38:11  #> >> done...                    2024-05-22 12:38:11 #> >> Method: edgeR #>  FDR:0.05& abs(logFC)<0 #> >> Estimating dispersion... #> >> Fitting GLM... #> >> DA peaks are found! #> >> No `geneset` is specified so immune modules (Chaussabel, 2008) will be used! #> >> enrichment.method` is not selected. Hyper-geometric p-value (HPEA) will be used! #> >> Mice gene symbols are converted to human symbols! #> >> Enrichment results are ready... #> >> Done!  pca_plot(results, contrasts, show.names = F)

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
text: Use prep_scATAC_cinaR() pseudobulk 10x scATAC peak--cell matrices cinaR-ready consensus matrix. preserves biological replicates (sample-level) avoids inflated significance per-cell testing. Per-cell-type (sample × cluster) pseudobulk: Seurat/Signac object: peak IDs chr:start-end, chr_start_end, chr-start-end format, pass peak.bed data.frame CHR, START, STOP columns via peak.bed = .... details please go site !
code: # counts: peak-by-cell matrix (dense or dgCMatrix) # meta: data.frame with rownames = cell barcodes # meta must include biological replicate and condition columns  prep <- prep_scATAC_cinaR(counts, meta,                           sample.col = "sample",                           group.col = "group")  results <- cinaR(prep$bed, prep$contrasts, reference.genome = "hg38") prep_list <- prep_scATAC_cinaR(counts, meta,                                sample.col = "sample",                                group.col = "group",                                cluster.col = "celltype")  results_list <- lapply(prep_list, function(x) {   cinaR(x$bed, x$contrasts, reference.genome = "hg38") }) prep <- prep_scATAC_seurat(seurat_obj,                            sample.col = "sample",                            group.col = "group",                            assay = "peaks")  results <- cinaR(prep$bed, prep$contrasts, reference.genome = "hg38")

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles
code: @article {Karakaslar2021.03.05.434143,     author = {Karakaslar, E Onur and Ucar, Duygu},     title = {cinaR: A comprehensive R package for the differential analyses and      functional interpretation of ATAC-seq data},     year = {2021},     doi = {10.1101/2021.03.05.434143},     publisher = {Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory},     URL = {https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.03.05.434143v2},     journal = {bioRxiv} }

title: A Computational Pipeline for Bulk ATAC-Seq Profiles

title: GSEA — GSEA
text: Gene set enrichment analyses, runs 'fgsea' package implementation preset values.

title: GSEA — GSEA
code: GSEA(genes, geneset)

title: GSEA — GSEA
text: genes DA gene names checked -represented . geneset Pathways used enrichment analyses. set vp2008 (Chaussabel, 2008) immune modules used. can set geneset using `read.gmt` function `qusage` package. Different modules available: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/downloads.jsp.

title: GSEA — GSEA
text: data.frame, list pathways enrichment (adjusted) p-values.

title: GSEA — GSEA
text: G. Korotkevich, V. Sukhov, . Sergushichev. Fast gene set enrichment analysis. bioRxiv (2019), doi:10.1101/060012

title: HPEA — HPEA
text: Hyper-geometric p-value enrichment analyses, looking -representation set genes given pathways.

title: HPEA — HPEA
code: HPEA(genes, geneset, background.genes.size)

title: HPEA — HPEA
text: genes DA gene names checked -represented . geneset Pathways used enrichment analyses. set vp2008 (Chaussabel, 2008) immune modules used. can set geneset using `read.gmt` function `qusage` package. Different modules available: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/downloads.jsp. background.genes.size number background genes hyper-geometric p-value calculations. Default 20,000.

title: HPEA — HPEA
text: data.frame, list pathways enrichment (adjusted) p-values.

code: data(atac_seq_consensus_bm)

title: cinaR — cinaR
text: Runs differential analyses enrichment pipelines

title: cinaR — cinaR
code: cinaR(   matrix,   contrasts,   experiment.type = "ATAC-Seq",   DA.choice = 1,   DA.fdr.threshold = 0.05,   DA.lfc.threshold = 0,   comparison.scheme = "OVO",   save.DA.peaks = FALSE,   DA.peaks.path = NULL,   norm.method = "cpm",   filter.method = "custom",   library.threshold = 2,   cpm.threshold = 1,   TSS.threshold = 50000,   show.annotation.pie = FALSE,   reference.genome = NULL,   batch.correction = FALSE,   batch.information = NULL,   additional.covariates = NULL,   sv.number = NULL,   run.enrichment = TRUE,   enrichment.method = NULL,   enrichment.FDR.cutoff = 1,   background.genes.size = 20000,   geneset = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: cinaR — cinaR
text: matrix either bed formatted consensus peak matrix (peaks 3+samples) CHR, START, STOP raw peak counts count matrix (genes 1+samples). contrasts user-defined contrasts comparing samples experiment.type type experiment either set "ATAC-Seq" "RNA-Seq" DA.choice determines pipeline run: (1) edgeR, (2) limma-voom, (3) limma-trend, (4) DEseq2. Note: Use limma-trend consensus peaks already normalized, otherwise use methods. DA.fdr.threshold fdr cut-differential analyses DA.lfc.threshold log-fold change cutoff differential analyses comparison.scheme either one-vs-one (OVO) one-vs-(OVA) comparisons. save.DA.peaks saves differentially accessible peaks excel file DA.peaks.path path excel file DA peaks saved, set saved current directory. norm.method normalization method consensus peaks filter.method filtering method low expressed peaks library.threshold number libraries peak occurs filtered default set 2 cpm.threshold count per million threshold filter peak TSS.threshold Distance transcription start site base-pairs. Default set 50,000. show.annotation.pie shows annotation pie chart produced ChipSeeker reference.genome genome interested species. 'hg38', 'hg19' 'mm10'. batch.correction logical, set run unsupervised batch correction via sva (default) batch information known `batch.information` argument provided user. batch.information character vector, given user. additional.covariates vector data.frame, parameter directly added design matrix running differential analyses, therefore affect batch corrections adjust results -stream analyses. sv.number number surrogate variables calculated using SVA, best left untouched. run.enrichment logical, turns enrichment pipeline enrichment.method two methodologies enrichment analyses, Hyper-geometric p-value (HPEA) Geneset Enrichment Analyses (GSEA). enrichment.FDR.cutoff FDR cut-enriched terms, p-values corrected Benjamini-Hochberg procedure background.genes.size number background genes hyper-geometric p-value calculations. Default 20,000. geneset Pathways used enrichment analyses. set vp2008 (Chaussabel, 2008) immune modules used. can set geneset using `read.gmt` function `qusage` package. Different modules available: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/downloads.jsp. verbose prints messages running pipeline

title: cinaR — cinaR
text: returns differentially accessible peaks

title: cinaR — cinaR
code: # \donttest{ data(atac_seq_consensus_bm) # calls 'bed'  # a vector for comparing the examples contrasts <- sapply(strsplit(colnames(bed), split = "-", fixed = TRUE),                     function(x){x[1]})[4:25]  results <- cinaR(bed, contrasts, reference.genome = "mm10") #> >> Experiment type: ATAC-Seq #> >> Matrix is filtered! #>  #> >> preparing features information...		 2026-02-02 12:27:44  #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> identifying nearest features...		 2026-02-02 12:27:45  #> >> calculating distance from peak to TSS...	 2026-02-02 12:27:45  #> >> assigning genomic annotation...		 2026-02-02 12:27:45  #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> assigning chromosome lengths			 2026-02-02 12:28:00  #> >> done...					 2026-02-02 12:28:00  #> >> Method: edgeR #> 	FDR:0.05& abs(logFC)<0 #> >> Estimating dispersion... #> >> Fitting GLM... #> >> DA peaks are found! #> >> No `geneset` is specified so immune modules (Chaussabel, 2008) will be used! #> >> enrichment.method` is not selected. Hyper-geometric p-value (HPEA) will be used! #> >> Mice gene symbols are converted to human symbols! #> >> Enrichment results are ready... #> >> Done! # }

title: Differential Analyses — differentialAnalyses
text: Runs differential analyses pipeline choice consensus peaks

title: Differential Analyses — differentialAnalyses
code: differentialAnalyses(   final.matrix,   contrasts,   experiment.type,   DA.choice,   DA.fdr.threshold,   DA.lfc.threshold,   comparison.scheme,   save.DA.peaks,   DA.peaks.path,   norm.method,   batch.correction,   batch.information,   additional.covariates,   sv.number,   verbose )

title: Differential Analyses — differentialAnalyses
text: final.matrix Annotated Consensus peaks contrasts user-defined contrasts comparing samples experiment.type type experiment either set "ATAC-Seq" "RNA-Seq" DA.choice determines pipeline run: (1) edgeR, (2) limma-voom, (3) limma-trend, (4) DEseq2 DA.fdr.threshold fdr cut-differential analyses DA.lfc.threshold log-fold change cutoff differential analyses comparison.scheme either one-vs-one (OVO) one-vs-(OVA) comparisons. save.DA.peaks logical, saves differentially accessible peaks excel file DA.peaks.path path excel file DA peaks saved, set saved current directory. norm.method normalization method consensus peaks batch.correction logical, set run unsupervised batch correction via sva (default) batch information known `batch.information` argument provided user. batch.information character vector, given user. additional.covariates vector data.frame, parameter directly added design matrix running differential analyses, therefore affect batch corrections adjust results -stream analyses. sv.number number surrogate variables calculated using SVA, best left untouched. verbose prints messages running pipeline

title: Differential Analyses — differentialAnalyses
text: returns consensus peaks (batch corrected version enabled) DA peaks

title: dot_plot — dot_plot
text: Given results `cinaR` produces dot plots enrichment analyses.

title: dot_plot — dot_plot
code: dot_plot(results, fdr.cutoff = 0.1, filter.pathways = FALSE)

title: dot_plot — dot_plot
text: results cinaR result object fdr.cutoff Pathways smaller fdr values cut-shown dots. filter.pathways logical, filter pathways dot plot fdr values less `fdr.cutoff`.

title: dot_plot — dot_plot
text: ggplot object

title: dot_plot — dot_plot
code: # \donttest{ library(cinaR) data(atac_seq_consensus_bm) # calls 'bed'  # a vector for comparing the examples contrasts <- sapply(strsplit(colnames(bed), split = "-", fixed = TRUE),                     function(x){x[1]})[4:25]  results <- cinaR(bed, contrasts, reference.genome = "mm10") #> >> Experiment type: ATAC-Seq #> >> Matrix is filtered! #> >> preparing features information...		 2026-02-02 12:28:01  #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> identifying nearest features...		 2026-02-02 12:28:01  #> >> calculating distance from peak to TSS...	 2026-02-02 12:28:01  #> >> assigning genomic annotation...		 2026-02-02 12:28:01  #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> assigning chromosome lengths			 2026-02-02 12:28:03  #> >> done...					 2026-02-02 12:28:03  #> >> Method: edgeR #> 	FDR:0.05& abs(logFC)<0 #> >> Estimating dispersion... #> >> Fitting GLM... #> >> DA peaks are found! #> >> No `geneset` is specified so immune modules (Chaussabel, 2008) will be used! #> >> enrichment.method` is not selected. Hyper-geometric p-value (HPEA) will be used! #> >> Mice gene symbols are converted to human symbols! #> >> Enrichment results are ready... #> >> Done!  dot_plot(results) #> Warning: Removed 54 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`).  # }

title: pca_plot — pca_plot
text: ggplot object

title: pca_plot — pca_plot
code: #' library(cinaR) data(atac_seq_consensus_bm) # calls 'bed'  # creating dummy results results <- NULL results[["cp"]] <- bed[,c(4:25)]  # a vector for comparing the examples contrasts <- sapply(strsplit(colnames(bed), split = "-", fixed = TRUE),                     function(x){x[1]})[4:25]  ## overlays the contrasts info onto PCA plots pca_plot(results, contrasts) #> Warning: ggrepel: 13 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider increasing max.overlaps   ## you can overlay other information as well, ## as long as it is the same length with the ## number of samples.  sample.info <- c(rep("Group A", 11), rep("Group B", 11)) pca_plot(results, sample.info, show.names = FALSE)

title: prep_scATAC_cinaR — prep_scATAC_cinaR
text: Prepare 10x scATAC peak--cell matrices cinaR pseudobulking per sample.

title: prep_scATAC_cinaR — prep_scATAC_cinaR
code: prep_scATAC_cinaR(   counts,   cell.meta,   sample.col,   group.col,   cluster.col = NULL,   peak.bed = NULL,   min.cells = 20,   verbose = TRUE )

title: prep_scATAC_cinaR — prep_scATAC_cinaR
text: counts peak--cell count matrix (dense matrix sparse dgCMatrix). cell.meta data.frame rownames cell barcodes. sample.col column name cell.meta indicating biological replicate. group.col column name cell.meta indicating condition/group. cluster.col optional column name cell type/cluster. provided, output named list per cluster. peak.bed optional data.frame CHR/START/STOP columns peaks. provided, rownames(counts) parsed "chr:start-end" "chr_start_end". min.cells minimum number cells required per sample (per cluster used). verbose logical, prints informative messages.

title: prep_scATAC_cinaR — prep_scATAC_cinaR
text: list elements `bed`, `contrasts`, `group.info`, named list lists cluster.col provided.

title: prep_scATAC_cinaR — prep_scATAC_cinaR
code: # \donttest{ counts <- matrix(c(1, 0, 2, 1, 0, 1, 3, 0, 0, 2, 1, 0),                  nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) rownames(counts) <- c("chr1:1-100", "chr1:101-200") colnames(counts) <- paste0("cell", 1:6) meta <- data.frame(sample = c("S1", "S1", "S2", "S2", "S3", "S3"),                    group = c("A", "A", "B", "B", "B", "B"),                    row.names = colnames(counts)) prep <- prep_scATAC_cinaR(counts, meta, sample.col = "sample", group.col = "group",                           min.cells = 2) # }

title: prep_scATAC_seurat — prep_scATAC_seurat
text: Prepare 10x scATAC data Seurat/Signac object cinaR.

title: prep_scATAC_seurat — prep_scATAC_seurat
code: prep_scATAC_seurat(   object,   assay = NULL,   slot = "counts",   sample.col,   group.col,   cluster.col = NULL,   peak.bed = NULL,   min.cells = 20,   verbose = TRUE )

title: prep_scATAC_seurat — prep_scATAC_seurat
text: object Seurat object containing ATAC assay (typically "peaks"). assay assay name use; defaults Seurat::DefaultAssay(object). slot assay slot pull counts (default "counts"). sample.col column name object@meta.data indicating biological replicate. group.col column name object@meta.data indicating condition/group. cluster.col optional column name cell type/cluster. peak.bed optional data.frame CHR/START/STOP columns peaks. min.cells minimum number cells required per sample (per cluster used). verbose logical, prints informative messages.

title: prep_scATAC_seurat — prep_scATAC_seurat
text: list elements `bed`, `contrasts`, `group.info`, named list lists cluster.col provided.

title: prep_scATAC_seurat — prep_scATAC_seurat
code: # \donttest{ if (requireNamespace("Seurat", quietly = TRUE)) {   prep <- prep_scATAC_seurat(seurat_obj,                              sample.col = "sample",                              group.col = "group",                              assay = "peaks") } #> Error: object 'seurat_obj' not found # }

title: run_enrichment — run_enrichment
text: function run, enrichment pipeline wants called afterwards. Setting reference genome genome cinaR run given function!

title: run_enrichment — run_enrichment
code: run_enrichment(   results,   geneset = NULL,   experiment.type = "ATAC-Seq",   reference.genome = NULL,   enrichment.method = NULL,   enrichment.FDR.cutoff = 1,   background.genes.size = 20000,   verbose = TRUE )

title: run_enrichment — run_enrichment
text: results list, DA peaks list different contrasts geneset Pathways used enrichment analyses. set vp2008 (Chaussabel, 2008) immune modules used. can set geneset using `read.gmt` function `qusage` package. Different modules available: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/downloads.jsp. experiment.type type experiment either set "ATAC-Seq" "RNA-Seq" reference.genome genome interested species. 'hg38', 'hg19' 'mm10'. enrichment.method two methodologies enrichment analyses, Hyper-geometric p-value (HPEA) Geneset Enrichment Analyses (GSEA). enrichment.FDR.cutoff FDR cut-enriched terms, p-values corrected Benjamini-Hochberg procedure background.genes.size number background genes hyper-geometric p-value calculations. Default 20,000. verbose prints messages running pipeline

title: run_enrichment — run_enrichment
text: list, enrichment analyses results along corresponding differential analyses outcomes

title: run_enrichment — run_enrichment
code: # \donttest{ library(cinaR) data(atac_seq_consensus_bm) # calls 'bed'  # a vector for comparing the examples contrasts <- sapply(strsplit(colnames(bed), split = "-", fixed = TRUE),                     function(x){x[1]})[4:25]  results <- cinaR(bed, contrasts, reference.genome = "mm10", run.enrichment = FALSE) #> >> Experiment type: ATAC-Seq #> >> Matrix is filtered! #> >> preparing features information...		 2026-02-02 12:28:11  #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> identifying nearest features...		 2026-02-02 12:28:11  #> >> calculating distance from peak to TSS...	 2026-02-02 12:28:11  #> >> assigning genomic annotation...		 2026-02-02 12:28:11  #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> Using Genome: mm10 ... #> >> assigning chromosome lengths			 2026-02-02 12:28:13  #> >> done...					 2026-02-02 12:28:13  #> >> Method: edgeR #> 	FDR:0.05& abs(logFC)<0 #> >> Estimating dispersion... #> >> Fitting GLM... #> >> DA peaks are found!  results_with_enrichment <- run_enrichment(results, reference.genome = "mm10") #> >> No `geneset` is specified so immune modules (Chaussabel, 2008) will be used! #> >> enrichment.method` is not selected. Hyper-geometric p-value (HPEA) will be used! #> >> Mice gene symbols are converted to human symbols! # }

title: cinaR 0.2.6
text: Fixed plotting helpers (pheatmap ..., dot-plot scale, PCA palette) Wired norm.method/filter.method pipeline Made run_enrichment() robust input shape empty contrasts Added prep_scATAC_seurat() helper Seurat/Signac objects

title: cinaR 0.2.5
text: Added scATAC preprocessing helper prep_scATAC_cinaR() vignette example Added package citation file updated preprint URL Guarded annotatePeaks() missing ChIPseeker Fixed upcoming CRAN checks

title: cinaR 0.2.4
text: Bioconductor related packages suggested Added .on_attach() smooth CRAN checks

title: cinaR 0.2.3
text: CRAN release: 2022-05-18 Minor improvements

title: cinaR 0.2.2
text: comparison.scheme either set OVO (default) compare contrasts . ’s set OVA contrast compared rest.

title: cinaR 0.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-02 extra argument sv.number added user wants set number surrogate variables. info . verbose argument, default set TRUE. think, implemented really cool way! cinaRgenesets added vignette.

title: cinaR 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-01-05 heatmap_differential function able plot heatmaps given comparison. show_comparisons added see available comparisons plot differential heatmaps. heatmap_plot now renamed heatmap_var_peaks, makes sense.

title: cinaR 0.1.1
text: version even cooler, lol: Comparisons now sorted according contrast order Added bulk RNA-seq support/documentation Removed many dependencies Small bug fixes improvements

title: cinaR 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-14 cinaR published CRAN repository!
